The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

div.p: NORWICH: Printed by JUDAH P. SPOONER, for the AUTHOR, 1776.

q.p: What ſhall we ſay to theſe Things?—If GOD be for us, who can be againſt us?

div.p:
FROM the words we may note,
I. The importance of GOD's being for us.
II. What muſt abſolutely be done on our part, that the bleſſed GOD may be on our ſide, or for us.
III. How bleſſed it will be to have GOD for us.
I. The importance of GOD's being for us.

WE have, my dear Countrymen, entered into the moſt ſolemn, weighty, and extraordinary affair, that ever concerned America; an affair that will terminate in our final ruin, unleſs GOD be for us.— We have though I truſt with the greateſt reluctance, taken up arms againſt the King of Great-Britain, who is the moſt powerful prince in the known world, who has been a terror to all nations, who is the ſtrongeſt by ſea, and can command the greateſt navy of any nation whatever; a great part of which is now employed in bringing ſoldiers, arms, ammunition and 〈◊〉 to America, with a determination to ſubdue us—have taken Boſton, the metropolis of New-England—have made it a ſtrong garriſon to guard themſelves—many firſt blocked in as priſoners—others obliged to leave their pleaſant habitations;—have burned Charleſtown, a very fine and beautiful place, to aſhes—cauſed the inhabitants to
•• ave their habitations in flames;—have proceeded •• rther—have burned Falmouth, a place of vaſt value—men, women, and children, in the greateſt confuſion and conſternation, occaſioned by the roaring of their cannon, the devouring flames of their buildings—obliged to leave their dwellings in ruins—have immediate orders to burn all the ſea-ports from thence to Carolina—will certainly execute their cruel deſign, which in the iſſue will damage America not leſs than 50 millions of money. Now all this will certainly be effected, unleſs GOD be for us.—To have this great and mighty nation againſt us, and the great and dreadful GOD againſt us too, muſt be dreadful indeed! For if GOD be againſt us, all the victories we have already gained, will only ſerve to augment their fury, and bring all the power and force of Great-Britain on us, and perhaps joined with the ſtrength of other nations.— If GOD be againſt us, all the wiſe conſultations of aſſemblies and congreſſes will prove abortive, our armies will be defeated, our country will be ravaged, we ſhall be deſtroyed by the ſword, by the famine, and by the peſtilence; the ſword without, and terror within, will conſume us—a fire will be enkindled in his anger, that will burn to the loweſt hell— He will ſcatter us into corners—he will cauſe the remembrance of us to ceaſe, and deliver us up to the greateſt reproach—thoſe that hate us will rule over us, and we ſhall be treated as the worſt of rebels.—This will certainly be the fate of America, unleſs GOD be for us, and on our ſide.—Now, What ſhall we ſay to theſe things? If GOD be for us,
who can be againſt us? And if he be againſt us who can be for us, that is able to deliver us?
Shewing the way, and the only way for the deliverance of America from the moſt diſtreſſing calamities that ever befel any people.
THUS we ſee, my dear friends and countrymen, that it is all-important that GOD be for us. Which brings us to conſider, in the
II. Place, What muſt abſolutely be done on our part, that the bleſſed GOD may be for us.

AND here, Firſt, Was is Liberty that firſt cauſed the ſettlement of this country?—Was this land deſigned by God himſelf for a land of liberty?—Was this the tenor and condition of the grant of this country from God to our forefathers, that no tyrant ſhould ever reign here?—Is this the only thing the Americans are ſuing for?—Was it their aſſerting their rights to this precious jewel, that has drawn the ſword againſt us?—Is it liberty that has ſet the nation in ſuch a terrible convulſion?—Then it will certainly appear, that all thoſe laws, cuſtoms, and practices, that infringe on the liberties of mankind, and are repugnant to the law of God, muſt be done away. Every thing that has any tendency to bind the conſciences of God's Children, of what name or denomination ſoever, muſt be done away. As we would have the Lord on our ſide, we muſt ſet at Liberty thoſe vaſt numbers of Africans, which have ſo long time been inſlaved by us, who have as good a right to Liberty as we have—We muſt no longer exerciſe that Cruelty and Barbarity towards
them, as we have heretofore done—We muſt put a final ſtop to all vexatious Law ſuits, and no longer exerciſe that Cruelty among ourſelves that even heathens would not be found guilty of—We muſt for ever ceaſe from this ſo ruinous a Practice—We muſt be kind and benevolent to the Poor—help and deliver them out of all their troubles and diſtreſſes— break every yoke, and every heavy burden, & let the oppreſſed go free. See Iſa. 58, 7, and on—We muſt be ſincere in our endeavors for Liberty, without any wicked or avaricious ends or deſigns for riches or honours to aggrandize ourſelves or children— We muſt faithfully improve all our ſpiritual privileges, and prize them above every thing elſe—We muſt have as much zeal to improve them as we have to contend for them, and then the Lord will never ſuffer them to be taken from us.—We muſt heartily aſcribe the glory of all the victories obtained by us, to GOD alone; and go, if called to it, againſt our enemies, as King David went againſt Goliah, in the name and ſtrength of the LORD GOD of Iſrael—We muſt continue that union and unanimity that ſubſiſts between the colonies, and unite, as one man, in putting away all thoſe ſins and abominations which is the cauſe of God's controverſy with us,—and continue to humble our ſelves in the united public manner as was once appointed by the Grand Continental Congreſs; which was the moſt extraordinary affair that ever happened in America: ſince which time we have been wonderfully defended; and we have the greateſt incouragement to take this method for deliverance, whenever thought proper
by thoſe wiſe Men who are ſet at the helm of affairs, and are appointed guardians for the ſeveral Colonies—We muſt break off all our ſins by righteouſneſs, and our iniquities by ſhewing mercy to the Poor;—then God will be for us, and all the powers of Earth and Hell will never deprive us of thoſe privileges. Now, What ſhall we ſay to theſe things? If GOD be for us, who can be againſt us? If GOD be for us, he can eaſily defeat the cruel deſigns of our enemies many ways: He can raiſe a tempeſt in the ſea, that ſhall toſs their ſhipping to the heavens, and bury them in the depths, and hurl them back from whence they came, or to ſome other remote part of the earth, or daſh them one againſt another, or againſt ſome unſeen reef in the ſea, and ſink them to the bottom. He can defeat them by ſending ſickneſs among them, and deſtroy them by the peſtilence, or by ſending faintneſs into their hearts, or granting us the victory if engaged in battle. He that ſits at the helm of all the affairs of the univerſe, and rules in the court of heaven above, can ſo over-rule things in the court of Great-Britain, as to cauſe all thoſe cruel acts to be nullified, their ſhipping and armies recalled, our ſeaports all opened, Boſton and other places all reſtored to their proper owners, the great breach healed, that ancient union reſtored, and the Americans put into the poſſeſſion of all their rights on a laſting foundation.

THUS we ſee, my dear friends and countrymen, how many ways the bleſſed GOD may interpoſe in our behalf—the laſt of which is to be the moſt deſired by every American; for it ſeems a pity the
Engliſh nation ſhould be broke like a potter's veſſel; the nation whom God has exalted to heaven—in which has been more of the glory of God to be ſeen, than in all the nations in the world beſides—the nation whom God has exalted to ſuch glory, honor and dignity.—O Britons! why wilt thou ruin thy ſelf, rip out thine own bowels, run the ſword into thine own heart, undo thy ſelf and thy moſt obedient children, the moſt loyal ſubjects in all thy vaſt dominions! Why ſhouldeſt thou, who haſt been the glory of all nations, become the reproach to all nations! Why wilt thou do that which will provoke God to caſt off the nation forever, and withhold his glory forever! Thou who haſt been the admiration of all foreigners for thy moſt excellent conſtitution, and haſt excelled all nations for thy kindneſs and hoſpitality, even to ſtrangers! Witneſs the vaſt numbers of French and others in the City of London, from all parts of the world—diſtreſſed ſtrangers and foreigners have been receiv'd with the greateſt kindneſs and indulgence.—Great numbers of French and others have been naturalized and permitted to ſet up trade in the city of London, and have grown very rich thereby, by the unexampled beauty of the natives; for hither they came deſtitute of every thing, and by public and private charity were put into a way to provide for themſelves and families. From the Revolution to this time, fifteen or twenty thouſand pounds has been paid to them annually by authority, towards ſupporting their poor. Now who could have thought the nation that has been ſo full of kindneſs and benevolence to ſtrangers, could become
ſo cruel to their own Children? Who could have thought a few years paſt, that ſaw the Engliſh nation in her meridian glory—that ſaw the univerſities in England, Oxford and Cambridge, which conſiſted of near 40 Colleges, out of which proceeded ſwarms of the beſt men who have appeared moſt eminent both in Church and ſtate—that ſaw the preſent King aſcending the throne to ſway the Britiſh ſcepter —that ſaw the Proclamations iſſued forth from under his royal hand and ſeal, diſcountenancing vice and immorality, and encouraging virtue and true religion. Who was there, 20 years paſt, that beheld the harmony that ſubſiſted between Britain and her Colonies—that ſaw the wide Atlantick full of veſſels laden with effects from America, bound to our native country—who could have thought, I ſay, that all the powers of Earth and Hell could have produced ſo ſudden an alteration, as to ſee the ſame ocean full of ſhipping from our mother country, bound to America, laden with ſoldiers, arms and ammunition, and all manner of inſtruments of death and cruelty, to deſtroy her own Children! Who could have thought a little deteſtable Tea, thrown into the ocean by a factious mob, ſhould be the cauſe of an ocean of bloodſhed, and forever diſſolve that union that was worth more Tea than the Eaſt-Indies produced? How much below the dignity of the nation are thoſe ſevere proceedings? Conſider, whilſt thou art pouring out thy hot thunder bolts on the Americans, what thou art doing, leſt the Almighty God pour out his wrath on thee for every drop of Blood ſhed in this unnatural controverſy,
binds the curſe of GOD on the nation, and will provoke GOD to leave it, and forever withdraw his glory from it never more to return, as he has from other nations and kingdoms. Methinks the words of the Prophet are applicable here, O thou ſword of the Lord, how long will it be, ere thou wilt be quiet? Put up thyſelf into thy ſcabbard, reſt and be ſtill—or turn thyſelf againſt ſome avowed enemy, not thy beſt friends: And thoſe of our Saviour, when he wept over the city of Jeruſalem, ſaying, O Jeruſalem! hadſt thou but known in this thy day the things that belong to thy peace; but now they are hid from thine eyes! And, O Jeruſalem! Jeruſalem! how often would I have gathered thee, as a hen gathereth her chickens under her wings, and ye would not! And as in Hoſea 9. 8. How ſhall I give thee up, Ephraim! How ſhall I deliver thee, Iſrael! How ſhall I make thee as Admah! How ſhall I ſet thee as Zeboim! My heart is turned within me, my repentings are kindled together!—How ſhall I leave the nation whom I have taken into ſuch a near relation to myſelf, and made comely thro' my comelineſs; which I have put upon high! Muſt I leave her, as I have other nations and places!—How ſhall I forſake Great-Britain, as I have left Jeruſalem!—Go ye now into my place which was at Shiloh, and ſee what I did to it for the wickedneſs of my people Iſrael.—Go ye thro'out all the eaſtern parts of the world, where they were once illuminated with the light of the glorious goſpel, and ſee how they are overwhelmed with ignorance, ſuperſtitions and hereſies—What I have done to the ſeven churches of Aſia—Look into Africa—time
was when there were thouſands of glorious churches there—Into Europe, and ſee from how many places GOD has removed his glory.—There was once in Rome itſelf a glorious church.—Look into Spain, and the Spaniſh low countries, which had once the glorious goſpel in them; but how has the bloody inquiſition extinguiſhed the light of the glorious goſpel in that unhappy kingdom!—Into Bohemia, and ſee now where is their glory?—Into Hungary, and the great kingdom of France; how has their wickedneſs provoked God to leave that unhappy kingdom!—Time was when there were hundreds of proteſtant miniſters and churches there; but how has a Babyloniſh king made them an empty veſſel, ſwallowed them up like a dragon, and caſt them out! And now, muſt Great-Britain ſhare the ſame fate? Muſt Great-Britain come to nothing, to deſtruction and diſſolution? for this is the certain fate of every kingdom divided againſt itſelf.—O that my head were waters, and mine eyes a fountain of tears, then would I weep day and night for the ruin of the Engliſh nation.—Is there no way to prevent this ruin?— Is there no balm in Gilead? no phyſician there, for the healing this deadly wound?—Why wilt thou not hold out terms for reconciliation, and let the breach be healed?

O America! what is the cauſe of GOD's controverſy with thee?—What haſt thou done, that has provoked GOD to write his diſpleaſure againſt thee in ſuch bloody and fiery corrections?—Canſt thou behold all the miſery that is come on thee, and immagine thou haſt done nothing to offend a holy,
juſt, and righteous GOD?—Canſt thou caſt thine eye upon thy ſeaports, from Falmouth to Carolina, and ſee the ocean full of engines of death, deſtined for the deſtruction of America—look into Boſton, that fine metropolis—view it taken out of the hands of the proper owners—look into thoſe fine and beautiful houſes, once devoted to the worſhip and ſervice of GOD, once filled with his glorious preſence, now turned play-houſes and riding-houſes, places, to furniſh their horſe for our deſtruction!—Who was there that ſaw the burning Charleſtown—that ſaw the flames aſcending from the lofty ſteeples of thoſe beautiful buildings, once devoted to the worſhip of the great GOD;—I ſay, to ſee the flames aſcending to the heavens—to hear the cracking and falling of the buildings—that heard the roaring of the cannon—the cries and groans of the wounded, they wallowing in their blood—the dead lying in heaps—look into Cambridge, and ſee thoſe colleges, which were once ſeminaries of learning, places to fit and train up perſons for the moſt ſacred work of the goſpel miniſtry, and to be phyſicians for wounded immortal ſouls—I ſay, ſhall we ſee thoſe colleges, that were once conſecrated to this ſacred and important buſineſs, now turned into hoſpitals, full of wounded bodies, and not ſuſpect ſomething has been amiſs in thoſe colleges?—See the ruin that has come on thoſe churches, and not ſuppoſe there are things introduced contrary to the word of GOD, and very provoking to him?—Methinks we can have no greater precedent of the wrath of Almighty GOD, than theſe things are. Surely we can have no greater
evidence that our ſins have reached to heaven, and cry for vengeance upon us; and that he will not be for us, but againſt us, unleſs we turn to him by unfeigned repentance: For ſo long as we hold faſt our ſins, and retain our iniquities, and do not turn to GOD, do not regard the works of the LORD, nor the operation of his hands, notwithſtanding he has been ſpeaking to us by terrible things in righteouſneſs—been threatning us with drought and ſore ſickneſs—taking away many by death;—and now, add to all this the withdrawing of GOD's holy Spirit—ſuſpence of divine influence—hardneſs of heart —blindneſs of mind;—Now, all theſe together, makes it very evident there never was a people nigher the brink of final ruin than we are; and as long as we continue in this careleſs, ſtupid, and indifferent ſtate, we declare by our practice, we have not done amiſs, our ways are equal, we have not done any thing to merit thoſe evils from the hand of the Lord. We anſwer by our practice, as Pharaoh anſwered Moſes, Who is the Lord, that we ſhould obey him?— By this means we reflect infinite diſhonor on the wiſe Governor of the univerſe, for puniſhing an innocent people. And here ariſes the controverſy between the great GOD and us—juſt as when a kind father corrects a rebellious child, his aim is to bring him to obedience, and to his duty; now if the child is regardleſs of his father's corrections, and will not turn for the ſtripes his father gives him, there is an abſolute neceſſity for a more ſevere correction;— and if he will not finally turn, he caſts him off as a rebel, and lets him go on, and fill up the meaſure
of his cup: But if the child turns to his father, and to his obedience, the father's heart is full of pity, his bowels yearn with compaſſion, his arms are open to receive him, and treat him with the moſt parental affection.—Juſt ſo the bleſſed GOD has for many years been dealing with America—he has been manifeſting his ſore diſpleaſure againſt us—he has been moſt ſeverely correcting us—his ſtripes have been moſt ſeverely laid upon us.—Now, if we ſtill go on, and will not remove the cauſe of his controverſy, there is a neceſſity of his ſtripes being laid on more ſevere; for GOD never began a controverſy with any people, that ever ended in any thing ſhort of their reformation or final ruin. And this is the caſe with us. If we turn to GOD, put away thoſe laws, cuſtoms and practices, thoſe ſins and abominations that are the cauſe of his controverſy, and turn to him by unfeigned repentance, take his word for our rule, ſhake the duſt from off our bibles, and let this be the compaſs to ſteer our courſe by, and walk ſo that our ways pleaſe the LORD; our calamities will ſoon ceaſe, our enemies will be at peace with us, the great and eternal GOD will be for us and on our ſide. 'Tis in this way, and no other, that we can have the LORD for us. Thus it was when God puniſhed Iſrael with three years famine, king David was very ſolicitous to know the cauſe of GOD's anger; and no ſooner had he found out, and done as the LORD required in this matter, the heavens could no longer withhold the rain, the earth was repleniſhed, and bro't forth her fruit. So it was with Joſhua, after his defeat at Ai. The next ſtep he takes, is to
ſearch after the cauſe of GOD's anger; and as ſoon as he had put the accuſed thing out of the camp, GOD was for him, and with him, and his enemies could not ſtand before him. In like manner, when the mariners had taken Jonah into their ſhip, it cauſed a terrible ſtorm in the ſea, which mounted her to the heavens, and buried her in the depths, and filled them with dreadful diſtreſs; they were very ſolicitous to know the cauſe of GOD's anger, and as ſoon as they had thrown Jonah overboard, the ſea was a perfect calm.—So it would be with America— Could we find out the cauſe, and throw the Jonah overboard, the nation would be in a perfect calm, and GOD will certainly be for us, and on our ſide.
III. And laſt thing propoſed; that is, to ſhew How bleſſed we ſhall be if the bleſſed GOD be for us.

AND now, What ſhall we ſay to theſe things?—If God be for us, who can be againſt us?—He will be a wall of fire round about us, and the glory in the midſt of us:—He will defend us from all the inſults of men or devils.—All thoſe wiſe and good men, who are at the helm of affairs, and are appointed guardians for the colonies, if they are inſtrumental of a thorough and univerſal reformation, will ſhine as lights in the world; their memories will be dear and precious to the lateſt poſterity; and they will not only ſhine in this world, but in the world to come, in the kingdom of glory, as ſtars of the firſt magnitude—Thoſe churches in this land will be favored with the divine preſence and glory of GOD—We ſhall be bleſſed in our baſket and ſtore, in our goings
out and comings in—We ſhall no longer hear the ſound of the trumpet, or alarm of war, nor ſee garments rolled in blood—thoſe inſtruments of cruelty ſhall be turned into the harmleſs utenſils of huſbandry—We ſhall be bleſſed with both peace and plenty—a foundation will be laid to enjoy them to the lateſt poſterity—our root ſhall be ſpread by the waters, and the dew ſhall lie on our branches— We ſhall enjoy all thoſe privileges that CHRIST has purchaſed for us, and which we have in conſequence of that eternal covenant that was made between God the Father and God the Son; which covenant was ratified in the counſel of his eternal peace and was fulfilled when he ſhed his precious blood on the croſs; through which channel flows every mercy and every favor that ever any of the human race ever did or ever will enjoy; for all was loſt by the fall and apoſtacy of our firſt head and repreſentative, and all was purchaſed by our ſecond; and in this ſenſe, and this only, he is ſaid to be the Saviour of all men.—Now, if GOD be for us, all thoſe mercies will as naturally flow to us, as the rivers flow into the ſea.—Now, What ſhall we ſay to theſe things?— If GOD be for us, who can be againſt us?—Surely, if GOD be for us, we need not apply to France, Spain, or Pruſſia, for protection; for the bleſſed GOD will protect us.
THUS we have conſidered the importance of having GOD for us—We conſidered what muſt abſolutely be done, that GOD may be for us— And likewiſe, how bleſſed it will be to have GOD for us.

AND now, my dear friends and countrymen, 〈◊〉 we are all concerned in this moſt ſolemn affair, how highly does it become us, to endeavor to remove every impediment that hinders GOD's being for us, and on our ſide!

closer.signed: A HEARTY FRIEND TO ALL THE COLONIES.
